div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

OCCUPATION OF EGYPT
FRENCH OPINION
(Gerettes Special Service )

_—- London, Friday Mr Barres, Freneb Depoty and Academician, has just retorned to Paris from Egypt. Inter viewed by “L'Eclair’, he said that under the existing condition of affairs in Egypt, no Egyp tian could seriously desire the disappearance of European Advisers. If England retired and were not succeeded by a European nation the result would be a return toanaroby This would be intolerable to the fellabin, who are now ao cnstomed to justice and equity He deecrihed Nationalism as a genuine feeling without any precise political object
SOCIETY FOR THE PROTECTION OF CHILDREN

A Society for the Protection of Children has recently been started in Cairo. The founder is Dr Abdel Aziz Narmi, medica! adviser to the hospital of the Wakts Administration and Hussein Pasha Rouchds is the President. This Society is entirely due to native initiative and ix consequently especially noteworthy as a mgn of Egyptian Renais-ance So far as the native concerned the whole field of social and sanitary refortin remains up to the present virgin soil He has bitherto considered it nene is of lis bi siness, acd bas been content to rely solely upon the Government to introduce and euforce the needful ameliorations Indeed, he is for ever clamouring fer aid from the public au thorities, aud apparently would welcome what wein England shonld call grandmotherly inter terence, thus testifying to the backwardness of Private effurt and the duty of self-help have hardly a» yet dawned upou bim. "The Governments, nv duabt, can do it has alrealy done something, though scarcely enough—in the matter of sanitation, tor example, but as regards social regeneration its sphere of action is obviously crreumsoribed within the varrowest possible limita. All it ean effect is to itmport a certain amount of the schools which it his political education. much moral tuetructiog tp manages or controls Tou what extent it fulfils this Obligatiou we are net abe to speak from per-onal observation So far however as our knowledge, gained at second bard, goes, this luty is discharged in as mewhat perfunctory manner What a glorious work it would be if a fale Proportion of those Eyyptians «ho flock in ninbers to the caf s where they pass the yreater part of their time ww rea hing the ‘‘Lewa’ and discussing inauites could be weaned from sich ap aimless existence and induced to take ai earest aud active interest in lessening the aom of bumen suffering, disease and misery Clearly the task isa tremendous one, demanding years of patient, atrenuvuus and self sac icing endeavour for it. of a people which lies around them accomplishment. The habits “un only be changed by slow degrees The attewpt however is well worth making and de-erves every encouragement. With his usual generosity and foresight His Highness the Khedive. it is anno peed, bas granted out tthe Wakts which be administers, an annua! ubvention of LE 1000 to the nealy formed weiety That is an excellent beginning ; and it is to be hoped that the en ightened exawple set by His Highness may be extensively follow el! by h« loyal subjects: No one bas forgotten how liberal was the response made by wealthy by y pte sto an official appeal for the endow ment of education. The need, in this instance, for both tidividual and collective Dr Nasmi and his however, help is far more pressing. deve te it h, 1 iteligent and @eueretic oof workers are said to be both All their energy and intelligence wil! undoubtedly be called ite play if sucees antic task is ever to be obtained sin thus praise worthy but SS

MENA HOUSE.

This botel has been very nearly full this week, and many people have been spending their Bairam holidays onder its roof. The offi. cers from the camp near at band have been using the hotel as their head quarters, and their presence has done meh to enliven the guesta staying there The handsome dining ball contained many cheery parties on Wed- nesday, and in addition to ita regelar habitués several parties had come from Cairo to parti. cipate in the subsequent dance which was held in the well known bal!. Atone table the Rev. and Mrs Urquhart were presiding over s party which included Miss Porrester, Miss Willis, Schaich Bey, Mr. Franks, Mr. Trelawny etc. at another Mra. de B. Carey from Ghetireb Palace was chaperoning Princess Irene, Miss Carey, Lord Peilding, and Messrs. Grey, Porber and Kirkpatrick Mrs MacMillan also from Gherireb had a party of four: Mrs Geddes and ber daughter aiso had friends : Miss Stuart Davidson was with another party : while that ot Sourour Bey numbered twelve. Mrs. Wood and Miss Bickham who bad arrived that day were present with friends, while other- noticed in the dining hal! were Colonel! aod Mrs. Ladlow, Mr. and Mra. Jobu Glen and their daughter, Mra Koch, the Hun. Claude Gork, Mr Rentians, Mr. and Mme Giulio Silva Coronel, Mr. and Mra Rafferty etc Barly hours are kept at Mera, and soon after nine o'clock strains of music attracted the more energetic members of the party to the hall which had been cleared and polished for dancing. Wa'tz’s and two steps kept most people husy till midnight, frequents visits being paid during the igtervals to the library, where a generous buffet had been erected There is something about the ait of Mena which always makes for enjoyment, and this evening was no exception to the rule. The gathering quite large enough to provide a sufficiency of partners, and yet not too large to be sociable, the programme was most thoroughly toilettes were worn by the ladies presént ; the pink frock worn by Miss Geddes with its silky stripes and light touches of silver being particularly fresh and dainty There were touches of silver tissue about the emerald green chiffon frock worn by Miss Forrester over an underdress of white ; and Miss Willis pink gown was veiled with an empire tunic of white vet bordered with satin, Princess Irepe was in cream satin inset with lace, Miss Davidson's frock was pale green satin slashed and embroidered about the corsage and showing glimpses of gathered chiffon, Mrs Glen was in pale blue, ber little daughter was of course in white. Most of the onlookers had retired before programme was over, and soon after twelve the waning lights warned the belated that their time was growing short Those who bad the journey back to Cairo to accomplish had to hurry into their wraps and start their journey lit only by the cold rays of the moon, but comforted not a littl by the the cheery farewells that sped them on their way Among the latest arrivals at Mens House Hotel are Mustapbe Pasha Febmy, Comtesse Chamare, Mme Carlotta Feliciani, Mme von Bernuth, Miss Woollard, Mr. and Mme Giulio Silva Coronel, Moh. Sourour Bey, Schalck Bey, Capt and Mrs. Hamilton, Mra and Mise de le Penha, Miss Walford, Mr and Mrs. Rafferty,

17, 1908 "THE OASIS RAILWAY.
TODAY'S CEREMONY.
(Prom Our Spaciat OonazsrowpewT)

Qara, Friday, 10. 30 am The special train from Cairo, bearing the guests invited by the Corporation of Western Egypt to assist at the opening of the Western Oasis Railway, arrived ponctoally at 7 o'clock thie morning at Kbarga Junction where the new line leaves the State Railway Breakfaxt was served on the train, and the visitors then chang. ed trains and boarded the comfortable new carriages of the company, which are to bear them across the hitherto little known regions of the Lybian Desert.

Kharga Junction is situated some four kilo- metres to the north of the market town of Far shat and about ¢ight from the better-known sugar centre of Nag Hamadi The line for the first four kilometres runs on one of the irriga- tion embankments of the Government, emerging into the open desert t & picturesque old horial ground at. the village of Karnak, where the railway base of the company is situa- ted, and where the opening ceremony was per- formed. The base station stands on the high ground, which borders the desert at this point, and the order!y arrangements of the white wash ed houses, the flag staffs upon which the Eo glish and Egyptian flags floated proudly side by side, suggest rather a Coast Guard station at home than the base of construction for a new railway. The train drew up opposite to the bungalow ocenpied by Mr. William C Hornblower, the su perintendent of the railway ,and bere the passen- gers alighted to witness the inanguration. After an inspection of the station had been made, H B. Pakbry Pasha,the Minister of Public Works, performed the ceremony by which the line was declared open for traffic. This inangural pro cedure took the form of the unlocking of a first- class carriage with a silver key designed for the purpose, and which bore the inscription Corporetion of Western Egypt Weetern Onais Railway ; Opened 17th January 1408 by H.E. Hussein Fakhry Pasha oo its four sidea, and bis Excellency was also the recipient of a gold medal bearing the name of the Corporation and Railway on the one side and the device of an engine crossing the desert together with the name of the railway and the date of its opening on the other, presented by the Corporation of Western Egypt. The pre sentation of the key was made by Mrs. John aon. This ceremony over, no time was lost in making a start for the distant asia, and within an hour of its arrival at the Qara Base the train stéamed oet of the station again, the luncheon hoer being figed for 1.80 pm. at the sommit of the starp, which leads down into the naa. Pakbry Pasha had been specially deputed by bis Highness the Khedive to represent him at the opening ceremony and among those present this morning «— Mr. EB Manville chairman, Mr W_ Heaton- Armstrong M P., Major General Bullock, Mr. Mitchell Innes, Mr. A. Hooker, Liewt Frazer ADC, Capt The Hon H, Tretuses, The Hon. Bvelyn Trefases, Mrs. Johnson, Mrs Rees, Mr. H.T. Moutgomery, Major Liddel, Mr.J BR Gibeon, Mr B. Lang Anderson, W W Carey, Capt. Adams, Capt JCM. Hall, DSO, M. Seid Rovete, Joseph Cattaw Bey, Capt. R L Dawson, Mr. 8S. R Cook son, H.J Temple, H EB Pakhry Pasha, H.B BA. Johnsou Pasha, PP. Graves “TS. mee”, H.W Tite, Mons R.A. Hon, Mr A Burton Buckley, Mr. Perey Barnard, HV Hall, Mr W.C Scales, BE Dentamaro, F Gus man, H. Naos, Mons. Philippar, Bindi Bey Ibrahim “Bl Watan,” Mr R Snelling “Egypt ian Gazette,” Mons Armivjan, Mr. C. New man, Mr. Pervand Braon “Journal! do Caire,” Tadros Bey Shinouda ‘E) Masr,” Saad Be) Khalif, Sheikh Ali Youssef “Ei Moayad,” Mr A.W. Wylie, Mr. Leon Heller, Mr B. Eledes tein, Photographer, Max Collatto “Le Progres, | Mr. BP. Fotbergill, Mr. H.V. Hewlett ‘The ee Sphinx,” The Editor “Les Pyramicdes,” The | Editor “El Abram,” The Editor “I'[mparziale, ° The Editor “The Egyptian Morning News,’ I Eee and lies within a hundred yards of the rail- way. This ravine has been the main road to the Oasis for centuries, the remains of the Roman “Belass” or water jars being ill in evidence on every hand, though it has found impossible to remove some of the specimens which have been discovered, as, sand-driven to the thickness of « cigarette paper, they crumble away at the slightest touch The profasion in which camel grass thrives in the Wadi was responsible for an at. tempt which was recently made to discover water by sinking a well. The idea waa, however, abandoned alter excavation to a few metres depth had been made, as there was not a fuspioion of moistare visible in the soil It is bot ao unoommon sight to see gazelle browsing on this vegetation here, and jackals and the desert fox are numerous. At kilometre 80 there is a ratber fine natura! Sphinx standing to the left of the railway Looking at it in certain lights it bears a close resemblance to its more famous brother near Cairo A stiff grade of 1 in 45 at kTlometre 47 ends in ® cutting through « brilliant red shingle at what may be termed the top of the Wadi, althongh after a sharp descent on curving embankments for about balf a kilometre the line again takesan upward grade of 1 in 50 and the platean is reached A few kilometres forther on stands the first depot of the railway All the material for the second portion of the line baving been stacked at this point, and being conveved up to theadvancing railhead by an engine detailed for this purpose, the ground is fairly level at this point and is bleak and desolate enough, bat it gives asplendid idea of the desert, though to appreciate its hardships it should be seen in a sand storm. Still further onthe railway crosses a bed of lime stone, and here the great difficulties attendant upon the construction work will be evident, for the necessary materia! tor the embankment was exceedingly hard to obtain, all the earth in the vicinity of the road being for the most part composed of lime, and was useless for the purpose for which it was required, crumbling away to nothing as soon as any pressure was brought to bear upon it There are people who complain of the eternal sameness of the desert bat to any one who takes the trouble to study it in ita changing moods itis replete with life and colour end one can travel mile after mie withont once being wearied by any lack of vanety. And i! is so in this case, here you get a shimmering led of lime stone gleaming like a lake of silver iu the sunlight, and there the dark shadows of coutrast which are ever chang ing in their depth of colour, from brown to purple, from purple to black, and so on with a variety which is as infinite as the chenging colours of the sea At kilometre 92 the line passes within a few yards of an old Roman well. This point must have been at one time a centre of some impor tance, probably as a watering station, fur the broken remains of lamps and beads and potter of the Roman period are still to be found in ite vicinity. The Corporation wisely determined to clear this well of the sand which bad drifted in since ita disuse, but it was found to end in a bed of solid rock, the soil which bad been found to be damp in places being practically tree from moisture at the very bottom There are several rock cottings about this district, and these were the cause of an immen seamount of labour at the time when the formation embankment was being prepared. The rock was of copglomerated lime stone, and to increase the difhcalties in the way of its re moval, it was found to be perforated with fis snes through which the powder used for blas ting escaped, leaving the heavier portions of the material practically untouched The piles of stones used as |and marks by the Bedouin caravans are visible from time to time from the railway, every caravan which passed was supposed to add to the heap of stones by at least ove thus serving to diminish the possibi lities ot a future caravan betmg lost in the de sert When one is travelling in the comfort of a first class saloon one is apt to lose sight of the conditions which prevailed before such a mode of transit was possible, the®e is no more civili ring influence inthe worl than a railway, while the presence of telepbone posts make it more than ever difhcukt to imagine the appearance which this land must have borne betore the line was laid. Therefore these land marks of varying sizes fe: i The Editor “El Zaber,” The Editor “Kairon,” lose much of theu significance wlep seen now The Editor “Bl Minbar,’ Abdel Khali] Pasha Sariot Mudir of Assiout, Sanout Hanna, Seif | for Engines, | ing, Irn | Generation of | available for Land, River ‘A Rev. 8. DESCRIPTION OF THE LINE

The following left Cairo yesterday for Upper Egypt by the Hamburg and Anglo-American! The village of Qara with its Coptic charch 8.3. “Germania” :-— The Earl of Sandwich, | of many domes having been passed the line Mr. F. Abbot, Mr. and Mre Ducoté, Miss | carves away from the Nile valley and cultiva- Frieda Roth, Miss Else Lorenta, Count de} tion is seen no more until the palms of the Bethane, Miss de Bethune, Mise Maller, Mrs. | Oasis appear in sight. But a great part of the Adeline Reinecke, Mr. Reinecke, Mr. and Mrs. | scenery throngh which the railway passes is J. B. Adams, Mrs. George B. Wood, Miss A.J. | Ane in the extreme, as when at kilometre 25 leseletein, Mr. J. T. Parker, Sir Herbert Praed, the road sweeps revnd on a curve nearly 4 Mr. Otho Pitagerald, Mre Steart White, Miss | Kilometre long into the Wadi Sembud, which Bacon. leads it to the main platean of the Lybian desert beyond This Wadi was undoubtedly « pateral water course in ancient days, the marks left by the action of the water upon the rocks which forms its sides being plainly vistble in places. It washere that the company formed their quarry for the stone supplied to the Govérnwent last year for the pitching of their

125 | irrigation embankments in the valley. The eminently suitable for work of thi! not only om account of the increased the stone is ot excellent quality | iture which they would involve, but 'from the windows of o railway carnage, bot imagine this expanse of desert as it was with out the guiding track of rails and it will be realised of bow great importance they were to the traveller At kilometre 142, the track of the railway leaves that which was followed by the camel caravans of former days, and at kilometre 147 the descent into the valley of the Oasis begins The scarp is approached across the face of a plateau which rises above the surrounding depressions in the formation of the land, and which apparently stretcher away abead of the railways indefinitely. Therefore it is not until the decent is acteally commenced that one realizes that the narrow gorge through which the train is passing is io reality the entrance to the Ossie of Kharga, the great Oasis The next sixteen kilometres is one sharp descent with « maximum grade for a shortdistance, only. of about 1 in 40, carving round to avoid a jutting edge of rock, or passing through a cutting to avoid « precipice, thé railway winds and ourves through scenery which is magoificient in ite wildness, and appalling |n its desolation. Here ‘again the fossilired rewains of abel) fish are | moch in evidence, the land being In some places literally crested with the fossils of an ‘oyster like figh Cuttings for the formation of the railway have been avoided as tar as ° order to avoid as far as posible the ever present difficulties which come with the drifted sand, afew hours wind being more than suff. cient to render the passageof trein« onsafe. The company therefore wisely decided to increase the height of embankments where it was in any way feasible and so obviate the nedeasity of constantly employing gangs of men to clear away the driven sand from cuttings. At kilometre 151 the train passes cver a ravine of some thirty metres in depth, once apparently a water course . thoagh the oldest resident of the Oasis cannot recall having seen | it ander any other conditions than its present one of extreme dryness. Towards the end of the scarp a huge sand dune covering a dyke of rock crosses the line of the railway, and it was decided to lead up to thie by an embankment which now takes the trains nearly op to the level of the higher land which surrounds the ravine, and at kilometre 168 the’ train emerges into open country once more, the open valley of the Oasis. This point marks the termination of all difficulties of construction, the land from here being practically level, and earth for the formation of such embankments as are neces sary, plentiful

Trees appear plentifully scattered aboot the central part of the plain, and at length the date palms of Kharga itself, the capital of the Oasis, are seen dimly in the distance The line curves round to the headquarters of the asia, the site chosen being the one which was considered to be the most suitable for and central for the development of the land though some distance frm Kharga itself A few of the passengers who can be accomodated bere will alight for the night and the rest will proceed to the rail heed some few kilometres distant. With the opening of this railway to-day the Kbarga Oasis bas been placed within a run of about 19 hours of Cairo, and those alone who bave made the journey can adequatey ap- preciate the difficulties which lay in the wa of its construction. The lime bas been laid onder the superintendance of Mr. William C. Hornblower, who in ovunjunction with Mr. J. L. Jones the Engineer in charge of cons truction is to be lated upon the success which has attended their efforts. In the first place there was the material to be for. warded daily to the rail bead, apd the gangs employed upon construction to be kept sep plied with water and there were also the main. tenance gangs to be considered in this respect The scarp presen ted engineering difficulties of no mean nature bat the alignmeot chosen was un doubtedly the most surtable one which was to be found and the evostructional work could not have been improved upon. Por the whole length of the line running is true and even, indeed quite exceptionnally so for « narrow guage railway. The formation earth work was carried out by Messrs. Gosman and Dentemaro, engineers and contractors of 6 Sharia El Bovlac, Cairo, and this firm has added greatly to their already soond reputation for this class of work by the able manner in which they surmounted the innomerable difh- culties which beset them in the ish - ment of the task allotted to them on this occasion. Even providing that labour was easy to procure, the work in the scarp Was one which would tax any firm in its accomplish- ment, but to add to the difficulties of natare, it was extremely bard to obtain labourers to undertake the work required of them, Mr. Hornblower was ably supported in his work by Mr T A. Amstrong and mech of the credit tor the work which has so successfully carned through, most be accorded to him. The superntendence ot the mechanical work at the base devolved for the greater part of the time that the railway was ander constraction upon Mr. C. Saunders and upoa his retirement from the work in order to take up work nearer Cairo, Mr. Robson has carried on the depart mentin a very satisfactory manner

div.p: THE SEASON'S VISITORS

The visitor's lists this week all show a very decided and very welcome increase in numbers are doing a splendid business, while those in Cairo are like to be crowded out before the mouth has finished) The Beiram holiday set everyone on the move al! who could get away | from Alexandria have spent it in Cairo, many Cairenes taking the same opportunity to visit Helouan, Mena House and other places not to far removed from the capita! Al! sorts of amu sements have been devised and enjoyed by the visitors at Helooan and Mena dunny Beiram there have been tennis tourmamenta, golf mat chea, pienics and excursions for the daylight | hours and vanous cheery dances have occupied the evenings The Tewfk Palace Hotel is enjoying a better season than ever this year al! the rooms are occupied, and the visitors all testify to the excellence of the cuisine and the com fort of their accommodation. Lady Willoughby Broke 1# speuding the season there, and the Visitors list this week includes among many others the names of Judge Wakeman Lony, Mre Evbalez and Miss Frost, Mr E R Alder son, and Mr and Mra John Walker At the Grand Hotel, Helouan, are staying the Hon Charlies Algernon Parsons, FRS, J.P, -Northamberland, CB, son of the third Earl of Rosse, with Mre Parsons familiar to most in ita connection with the Marine Steam Turbine Co and be is personally responsible for the development and improve ments in the steam turbine, which have made it of such practical use for electrical, nava! and other purposes. He ts also a member of Mr. Chamberlain's tariff reform commision, Other visitors at the Grand Hotel are Baron René de Menasce and Lady Dorothy Glyn, wife of Sir Gervas Powell Glyn, of Burcote

Giuck, and Mogart devicacy, and punty of phrase at moments (the ececution 1 individual rather than geseral, ,aud these three great masters surely require absolute perfection and unity of exesuteon, if the thorvughness of their detailed thoaugbt is to be manttested. The Huwferdinek overture wae good, it is evidently far more suitable to the temperament of the performers. Two violin solos followed, a quaint Dvorak, in which the double stopping was the best part of the execation, and aa Albanian dance composed by the soloist: it began well, with some effeetive minor passages, notable for the tull tone 1. tervale that replaced the usual semitones and leading notes; but the middle — and greater part of it was simply “fireworks,” and asthe performer lacked de- cision, and ocoasionally accuracy, it was rather trying Borodin’s ‘Steppes of Asia’ was the 5th item, well enough given: it is a delightful aad characteristic piece, full of plaintive melody and original setting the high monotonous drone of the violins, the suppressed scberzo rythm, the clear decisive air that winds through and through it, retarning at the last to that same drone, — the whole of it is ouri ous, and suggests certain phases of Tristan, it is lovely music The Walkiran-Ritt was hardly a success: there were too few violine available, and conseqaently the flutes had undue prominence: and where were the cym- bals or the side drum! it was taken too slew, and its breadth and movement hiddem: the only point properly worked up was the finish M. Baron seemed to jose interest in it uati! the last few bars. Still these few details criti cised are of amal! importance, especially when we consider what we gain by hearing such cxcelleut music in Cairo, aad the really good execution of it as a whole amply compenates for the ocea-ional slight faults which are as much as anything due to the amount of work the orchestra has, apart from these con certs, and the consequent difheulty of giving all the time one could wish to rehearsala We owe the Suciété a large debt of gratitude, aod our best way of repaying it is to patronise their concerts extensively until they become a permanent and stable institntion. was well given and its digosty and depth | Paget, Campbell, Sir W. div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect. Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors from Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.
BAUING AT MINLEH,

(From ova own CogReapoupaeyr). The Second Winter meeting of the Minieb Sporting Club took place on Friday last, January 10. The attendance was not quite as good as cawal, probably owing to the blustery weather Amongst those present we noticed HE. The Madir, Hassan Bey Hassib, the Sub Mudir, Ahb Bey Gamal el Dine; Abd el Hamid Bey Abaza . Ahmed Bey Fathi , Keimakam Shukralla Abdella Bey . Abd el Auwiz Eff. Abaza ; Amin Eff. Zahran ; Mr and Mrs. Haselden, Mr. and Mrs. Aitkin, Mr. and Mrs Bray, Miss Gordon, Mme Stavranaeki, Mme Joaniddes, Messrs Langley, Bexwell, Bury, Murray, Dube, Hansard, and others too numerous to mertion, The absence of Omar Bey Sultan, the popular sapporter of the meeting was much regretted The course bas been very mech improved since last year, being now railed in. An excellent paddock has been made, with 34 boxes, all of which were filled. A new stewards stand has been erected, also stands for mem bers, and a first and second class enclosure have been provided, each with its own stand. Tea cam now be bad by all who wih it, and the taLles were well patronued. A weighing room and jockeys dressing room are new features this year. In fact most of the require menta of medern racing fulk are well provided tor—except certainties Appended is the programme.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers “Osiris" and “Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy’s most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, “Entombment," by Ciseri, and ‘Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D’OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
